title: 109_hr739
content:
The Act includes titles such as Occupational Safety and Health Small Business Day in Court Act of 2005, Occupational Safety and Health Review Commission Efficiency Act of 2005, Occupational Safety and Health Independent Review of OSHA Citations Act of 2005, and Occupational Safety and Health Small Employer Access to Justice Act of 2005. Each title contains sections with specific provisions. The "Occupational Safety and Health Small Business Day in Court Act of 2005" includes provisions amending Section 10 of the Occupational Safety and Health Act of 1970 related to contesting citations. The amendments made by this title apply to citations or penalties issued by OSHA on or after the enactment date. The title is known as the "Occupational Safety and Health Review Commission Efficiency Act of 2005." The Occupational Safety and Health Act of 1970 is amended to increase the number of members to five and add criteria for membership. The President may extend a member's term for up to 365 days. Vacancies can be caused by death, resignation, or removal. The Occupational Safety and Health Act of 1970 is amended to increase the number of members to five and add criteria for membership. Vacancies can be caused by death, resignation, or removal. New positions are created with specific appointment terms. TITLE III--OCCUPATIONAL SAFETY AND HEALTH INDEPENDENT REVIEW OF OSHA CITATIONS ACT OF 2005

This title allows for an independent review of OSHA citations, with conclusions given deference if reasonable. 

TITLE IV--OCCUPATIONAL SAFETY AND HEALTH SMALL EMPLOYER ACCESS TO JUSTICE ACT OF 2005

This title provides for the award of attorneys' fees and costs for small employers accessing justice. SEC. 402. AWARD OF ATTORNEYS' FEES AND COSTS. The Occupational Safety and Health Act of 1970 is amended to include a new section for the award of attorneys' fees and costs. Sec. 32 of the Occupational Safety and Health Act allows employers with fewer than 100 employees and a net worth of not more than $7,000,000 to be awarded fees and expenses as a prevailing party in certain proceedings, without considering the justification of the Secretary's position. This applies to adversary adjudications and judicial review proceedings. Employers meeting specific criteria can be awarded fees and expenses as a prevailing party in certain proceedings under the Occupational Safety and Health Act, without considering the justification of the Secretary's position. This provision applies to proceedings initiated after the enactment of this section. The provision allows employers meeting specific criteria to be awarded fees and expenses as a prevailing party in certain proceedings under the Occupational Safety and Health Act, applicable to proceedings initiated after the enactment of this section. The House of Representatives passed the bill on July 12, 2005.
